Graphical abstract Hydrogen gas was produced from the catalytic reformation of pyroligneous acid (PA)with modified bimetallic Al-SBA-15 catalysts. Al-SBA-15 catalysts with different aluminum loading contents were prepared through one-step hydrothermal synthesis. Monometallic M-Al-SBA-15 (M=Ni, Fe, Co, and Sn) and bimetallic M/N-Al-SBA-15 (M-N=Ni-Fe, Ni-Sn, and Ni-Co) catalysts were synthesized through impregnation. The catalysts were characterized via N2 adsorption-desorption, scanning electron microscopy(SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(XRD), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(XPS) analysis and so on. Bimetallic M-N-Al-SBA-15 catalysts exhibited higher catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance than monometallic M-Al-SBA-15 catalysts. Sn facilitated the combination of Ni with Al into a NiAl2O4 spinel in the carrier. Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 bimetallic catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance. The H2 yield was 30.1mg/g and H2 content remained 40% after 16h under the optimal reaction conditions via the Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 catalyst. Keywords Pyroligneous acid Rich hydrogen gas Bimetallic M-N-Al-SBA-15 catalyst NiAl2O4 spinel Carbon deposition resistance 1 Introduction Numerous studies have alleged that bio-oil, the liquid product of biomass pyrolysis, is a potential fuel with an important role in the future energy market. Bio-oil, however, has lower energy density than traditional fuels. In addition, bio-oils produced by different technologies has high viscosity, poor stability, and complex chemical compositions [1]. These poor physicochemical properties restrict the further application of bio-oils and hinder the development of pyrolysis technology. Bio-oil can be divided into heavy oil and light oil. Both of them are the important parts of the bio-oil, however their composition is different, which brings different properties [2]. Light oil, also known as PA, is bronze in color, contains as much as 60% water, and is corrosive [3]. Light oil is composed of organic compounds, such as phenols, ketones, aldehydes, acids, and alcohols, as well as alkaline components (e.g., amine) and inorganic matter (e.g., Na, Mg, Al, and Fe). Given its high oxygen content, PA has unstable chemical properties. Moreover, light oil is strongly acidic and could corrode devices. Furthermore, the low viscosity and high water content of light oil hinder its direct application [4]. Nonetheless, the properties of light oil are advantageous for hydrogen production. For example, the micro-molecular organic (C atoms less than 4) content of PA is easily decomposed into gases, and its high acid content is easily catalyzed into hydrogen. The direct pyrolysis of PA produces mixed gases with approximately 25% H2 content. Some researchers have attempted to produce hydrogen through catalytic reformation to obtain high-value clean fuel [5]. However, two problems are associated with catalytic reformation. First, the selection of the appropriate high-efficiency catalyst is impossible due to the complex ingredients of the raw materials. Second, carbon deposition on the surfaces of the catalyst during the reaction will poison and shorten the life of catalysts [6]. Numerous researchers have attempted to solve these problems [7–10]. Based on literature review, the appropriate carrier may provide the suitable reaction environment and reduce carbon deposition from accumulated macromolecular organics. SBA-15 is a common mesoporous material with a large pore diameter, thick pore walls, strong hydrothermal stability, and good physical structural properties [11–14]. SBA-15, however, is a pure SiO2 mesoporous material without catalytic activity. Some researchers have obtained SBA-15 with different properties through modification or synthesis with other materials [15–17]. Loading catalysts with active metals increases catalytic activity and catalytic selectivity while decreasing carbon deposition [18–21]. Nickel and cobalt catalyst were used in many domains, both of them show better catalytical properties. Onyestyak [22] compared two monometallic (nickel and cobalt) catalysts with bimetallic catalysts in the acetic acid reduction, It was shown that cobalt, opposite to nickel, can direct the consecutive catalytic reduction to ethanol formation inhibiting hydride-carboxylation. Wang [23] compared different Ni catalyst for the hydride-oxygenation of diphenyl ether, Ni/Al-SBA-15 was identified as the best catalyst for HDO of diphenyl ether. However, nickel and cobalt catalyst always show poor carbon deposit resistance ability, thus same other metal were found to protect them from the carbon deposit. Kathiraser [24] synthesized highly dispersed Ni-Fe bimetallic catalysts for the catalytic reforming of bio-oil. Among the various compositions tested, an optimum catalyst composition of 6Ni-1Fe/SBA-15 gave superior catalytic performance in terms of stability and activity. Wang [25] synthesized Sn-based solid catalysts for the conversion of biomass, has both Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites, resulting in superior catalytic activities in the acetalisation of glycerol. The modified SBA-15 exhibited good pore structure and improved dispersibility [26]. Ma et al. modified SBA-15 with La-Ni to obtain a catalyst with high loading capacity and uniform distribution. The order structure of the mesoporous materials was not destroyed, further demonstrating the advantageous physicochemical properties of SBA-15 [27]. The highly porous structure and stable physicochemical properties of SBA-15 favors further modification. SBA-15 should be modified with the appropriate active substances to increase its overall catalytic activity for the reformation of bio-oils, which have complex compositions [28]. He et al. [29] investigated that the ethanol steam reforming (ESR) for hydrogen via Ni/SBA-15 catalysts. And Calles [30] et al. synthesis the Cu-Ni/SBA-15 catalysts for hydrogen production through ethanol steam reforming. Rossetti [31] investigated the catalytic conversion of ethanol steam reforming in the low temperature range with SBA-15 catalyst. However, it is more interesting to investigate the catalytic reforming of bio-oil via modified SBA-15 catalyst due to the ccomplex of bio-oil. To improve catalytic activity and decrease carbon deposition in the catalytic reformation of pyroligneous acid, Al-SBA-15 samples with different Si/Al ratios were synthesized through one-step synthesis in this study. To prepare metal-monometal catalysts, Al-SBA-15 was modified with the transition metals Ni, Co, Sn and Fe. Furthermore, Al-SBA-15 was modified with bimetallic Ni-Fe, Ni-Co, and Ni-Sn. 2 Experiment 2.1 Pyroligneous acid Pyroligneous acid(PA) is a lightweight liquid present in the upper phase of crude bio-oils derived from biomass pyrolysis. PA is a dark brown liquid with a strong smoky smell. The main organic components of PA were acetic acid and phenols. Camellia shell was used as the raw material for the production of PA. The Camellia shell was obtain from a continue pyrolysis device [32], residence time was 8min and the pyrolysis temperature was 500°C. Pyrolysis gases were condensed using a glass condenser with water cooling. After the static layering of collected liquid products, the supernatant (PA) was collected. The PA components were analyzed with a GC/MS QP2010 Ultra using an Rtx-Wax column (30m*0.25mm*0.25μm film thickness). As shown in Fig. 1 , PA is mainly composed of organic compounds, such as acids, phenols, and ketones. Acids accounted for approximately 44.18% of the total organic compounds of PA. Few nitrogen-containing organic compounds exist in PA as well. The pH of PA was 3.5, which indicated strong acidity. The viscosity of PA was 1.08 cSt, which was approximately 10 times lower than those of whole biomass oils (14.35 cSt). Water content of PA was 83.2033wt.%. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of Al-SBA-15 Al- SBA-15 was synthesized via the one-step hydrothermal method. First, 4.0g poly(ethylene oxide)-b-poly(propylene oxide)-b-poly(ethylene oxide) copolymer Pluronic P123 (Mav1/45800, EO20PO70EO20) from Aldrich was dissolved in 120g (2mol/L) HCl. Then, 30g of deionized water was added to the solution, which was then magnetically stirred at a rate of 500 r/min under 36°C for 1h. Active γ-Al2O3 was ground to 1mm with a ball grinder. An appropriate amount of micron Al2O3 powder was added to the solution, which was then stirred for an additional 7h. After stirring, 8.4g TEOS was added to the solution. After 20h of reaction time, the solution was pump-filtered and washed to a neutral pH. All solids were dried at room temperature and then baked in a tube furnace at 550°C for 5h to eliminate the template. The obtained white powder was the raw Al-SBA-15. The samples were designated as 10-ALS, 5-ALS, and 2.5-ALS, corresponding to the ratio of Si/Al 10, 5 and 2.5. 2.2.2 Preparation of monometallic M-Al-SBA-15 and bimetallic M-N-Al-SBA-15 Deionized water was added to Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O. SnCl2 was dissolved in an aqueous solution of HCl. The 5-ALS support was impregnated in the solution to obtain the monometallic catalysts Ni-Al-SBA-15, Fe-Al-SBA-15, Co-Al-SBA-15, and Sn-Al-SBA-15. The content of Fe, Co, Ni, and Sn was 15% based on the mass of Al-SBA-15. To prepare the Ni-Sn-Al-SBA-15 catalyst, SnCl2 and nickel nitrate nonahydrate (Sigma) were dissolved in an aqueous solution of hydrochloric acid. Ni and Sn content were 12% and 3%, respectively, based on the mass of Al-SBA-15. Then, the 5-ALS support was impregnated in the solution. The mixture was subjected to ultrasonic shaking at room temperature for 30min and maintained at room temperature for 2h. The mixture was dried at 100°C for 24h and then calcined at 500°C for 3h in air. The method for the synthesis of Ni-Fe-Al-SBA-15 and Ni-Co-Al-SBA-15 was similar to that for the synthesis of Ni-Sn-Al-SBA-15. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts X-ray photoelectron (XPS) spectra were measured using a Thermo-Scientific spectrometer with operated atmosphere of 5×10−9 vacuum and monochromatized Al Kα X-rays (1,486.6eV). The binding energies of Ni2P and Al were analyzed using the Shirley and linear baseline correction, respectively. Specific surface areas and pore volumes were determined from N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms obtained at 77K using a Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390 gas-adsorption analyzer. The amount of carbon deposition on the spent catalysts was measured using the STA449C Jupiter® thermogravimetric analyzer. Approximately 8mg of sample was placed in a Pt crucible and heated at a rate of 10°C/min. N2 (30ml/min) was used as the protective gas. Air (30ml/min) was used as purging gas. Temperature was increased from 30 to 800°C. The Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Hitachi-S4800 FESEM) was used to investigate the surface morphology of the catalysts and the carbon deposited on the used catalysts. X Ray Fluorescence(XRF)(PANalytical −AxiosmAX Petro) used to determine the Si and Al to confirm the catalyst has the proper ratio of Si/Al. For the analysis of H2, gas chromatography (GC) was also performed, as in our previous research [32]. The crystallographic phases of the samples were confirmed by XRD measurements (D8 VENTURE Bruker, CuKα radiation). Powder patterns were collected within a 2θ range from 5 to 80 with a step of 0.02θ and 30s counting time for each angle. 2.4 Catalytic runs and product analysis Catalytic tests were carried on a fixed bed with quartz tube reactor. Which was showed in Fig. 2 . PA was continuously transferred to the quartz tube reactor from the pipeline by a peristaltic pump. The rate of the feedstock was set at 0.1ml/min by adjusting the peristaltic pump. The diameter, length, and thickness of the quartz tube reactor were 3cm, 100cm, and 0.3cm, respectively. The catalyst was placed in the catalyst bed in a quartz tube reactor installed in the middle of the pyrolysis furnace, which was supported by heat-stable cotton. Approximately 2g of the catalyst was used for the analysis [33]. The catalyst bed temperature was monitored by a central thermocouple in the catalytic cracking furnace, which was set to 700°C. PA was heated by the furnace and gasified before contact with the catalysts. Before testing, all catalysts were reduced in H2/N2 (10/90, vol.%) mixture, which was heated from 24°C to 700°C and retained at 700°C for 2h. After reduced, gas atmospheres was changed to N2, the flow rate was kept at 100ml/min. The gases produced via gas-phase catalytic cracking was collected in gas bags, while the liquid production was collected in the bottle. Then, the gas was separately subjected to GC analysis using an Agilent 6820 gas chromatograph (i.e., for H2, CO, CH4, CO2, C2H4, and C2H6) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), N2 carrier gas, and HP-PLOT-Q column (30-m length, 30°C). TCD temperature was 250°C, and separation was conducted at a 1:10 ratio. (1) Gas relative concentration was calculated as follows: W H 2 = V H 2 V C H 4 + V C O 2 + V C 2 H 4 + V H 2 + V C 2 H 6 * 100 % The calculation was similar for WCH4, WCO2, WC2H4, WCO, and WC2H6. (2) H2 yield (mg/g sample) H 2 y i e l d ( m g / g s a m p l e ) = W H 2 ∗ V ∗ 2 ( g ) m a s s o f f e e d s t o c k ∗ 22.4 ( g s a m p l e ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Experiment on SBA-15-catalyzed reformation of PA 3.1.1 Effect of Al content on Al-SBA-15 structure The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distribution curves of Al-SBA-15 with different Al loadings were obtained. As shown in Table 1 , the BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of SBA-15 were positively related with Si/Al ratio. When Si/Al ratio decreased from 10 to 2.5, the BET surface area of SBA-15 increased from 448.74m2/g to 536.06m2/g; its total pore volume increased from 0.279cm3/g to 0.347cm3/g, and its average pore diameter increased from 2.16nm to 3.16nm. It is obvious that the properties of the AL-SBA-15 were decreased with the Si/Al ratio decreasing, it is possible that, in the process of synthesis, aluminum stay at the wall of the hole occupied parts of the pore space and some of the aluminum may not in the bone of Al-Si. Therefore, the BET, pore size and pore volume decreased [34]. As shown in Fig. 3 , 10-ALS, 5-ALS and 2.5-ALS presented weak N2 hysteresis loops, indicating that these catalysts possess cage-type mesoporous channels. 10-ALS presented no N2 hysteresis loop, indicating that it had no evident mesoporous structure. On the basis of overall data, the porosity of Al-SBA-15 decreased as Al2O3 content increased, and the formation of mesoporous channels in Al-SBA-15 was simultaneously changed. Moreover, the dispersion of Al in the sample of 10-ALS is not good, resulting in the decreasing of BET surface. However, when Al content increased gradually, Al diffused throughout the whole system and formed a stable Si-Al structure, thus increasing the porosity of Al-SBA-15. Nevertheless, excess Al may combine with Si to form irregular structures. The addition of Al decreased the specific surface area of Al-SBA-15 and caused the pore size becoming small. Low angle XRD results of the 4 kinds of SBA-15 were showed in Fig. 4 , all of the catalyst has the obvious SBA-15 feature peaks. It indicated that the 3 kinds of AL- SBA-15 have same structure with the pure SBA-15. With the increasing of the Si/Al ratio, the feature peaks of (110) and (200) decreased and shifted to the lower angle, less aluminum could results in ordered structure formation, which strengthened the order degree of the SBA-15 and shifted the peaks to lower angle [35]. 3.1.2 Effect of Al content on catalytic performance A catalytic conversion experiment was conducted with the prepared Al-SBA-15 catalyst. To investigate the effects of Al content on overall catalytic performance, SBA-15 without Al was used as the blank control. Gas yield and content under different Al content catalyst are presented in Table 2 . Although the blank SBA-15 had no catalytic activity, PA was still converted into gases after thermal treatment. Organic matter in PA was decomposed into gases by thermo-chemical conversion. Decomposition depended on the rich pore channels of SBA-15, which provided more spaces for decomposition. The H2 yield, however, was still relatively low. After the addition of Al, gas yield continuously increased. Hydrogen and CO2 content increased, whereas ethylene and CO content decreased. Hydrogen yield exhibited the highest increase (2.16 times) whereas ethylene yield considerably decreased (6.9 times). The overall catalytic activity of Al-SBA-15 increased after the addition of Al. When Si/Al ratio decreased from 10 to 2.5, the overall gas yield first increased and then decreased. Similarly, hydrogen and methane yields increased and then decreased. When Si/Al ratio was 5, hydrogen yield reached 14.87mg/g and methane yield reached 51.62mg/g. Ethylene yield decreased and then increased. CO and CO2 yields gradually increased. Given the influence of the overall gas yield, the combined gas composition under different conditions was analyzed. Hydrogen content also increased and then decreased, whereas CO and ethylene contents presented the opposite trend. Methane gradually decreased, whereas CO2 gradually increased. Based on comprehensive analysis, the addition of Al facilitated reformation in recycled water (CH4 +H2O=CO+2H2, CO+H2O=CO2 +H2), thus increasing hydrogen content. The addition of excess Al to Al-SBA-15, however, did not further increase catalytic performance, instead of inhibiting the reaction. The variations in gas composition over 2h of reaction are shown in Fig. 5 . Without the addition of Al, the contents of different gases changed slightly with time, indicating that the pyrolysis of PA was relatively stable. After the addition of Al, gas composition fluctuated through time. When Si/Al ratio were 2.5 and 10, hydrogen content remained stable only during the first hour and then later decreased because Al and Si formed a SiAl structure, breaking the local structure was and thus inactivating the catalyst. Increasing Al resulted in excessive Al unevenly dispersing and blocking some pores, thus influencing the overall catalytic effect. When Si/Al was set at 5, hydrogen yield began to decrease at 40min of reaction time, then gradually stabilized (i.e., above 35%). This result demonstrated that the appropriate Al content will combine with the Al-SBA-15 skeleton and protect the internal pore structure of Al-SBA-15. Silicon is the main frame structure of SBA-15, the addition of Al increased the SBA-15 surface acidity, provides a new reaction site. Silicon and aluminum is the main part of the molecular sieve material, aluminum and silicon will form Si-Al structure during the process of preparation [36]. The structure will change the selectivity of catalyst. After adding aluminum, hydrogen concentration increased significantly, while adding amount was low limiting the change of selectivity. When the adding amount is too high, some of aluminum stay out of the Si-Al bone and decreases the properties of catalyst. Moreover, too much aluminum not only resulted in acid sites, but also increased the likable of carbon deposition [37]. 3.2 Catalytic reformation of PA with the SBA-15 catalyst 3.2.1 Effect of monometallic loading on catalytic performance Additional experiments for the modified catalysts were conducted. The variations in gas concentrations with time are shown in Fig. 6 . When Ni or Co was added, hydrogen content increased because Ni and Co formed a new activity center on the surface of the catalyst, thus enhancing catalytic activity. Fe and Sn, which only slightly influenced hydrogen content, existed as auxiliaries and were mainly effective in resisting carbon deposition. Although Ni and Co could facilitate catalysis, hydrogen content decreased gradually after a certain reaction time. When Co-Al-SBA-15 was used as a catalyst, hydrogen content began to decrease at 10min of reaction. Moreover, overall hydrogen content decreased from 57% at the beginning of the reaction to 43% at the end of the reaction. When Ni-Al-SBA-15 was used as the catalyst, hydrogen concentration gradually decreased at 30min of reaction and was reduced to approximately 10% at 120min or at the end of the reaction. However, Ni and Co catalysts have different reaction mechanism, Co catalyst is affinity to oxygen specie and carbon deposition, while Ni catalyst is mainly affinity to carbon deposition [38]. Therefore, although Ni and Co could increase hydrogen yield and form new activity centers, Ni catalyst could easily cause carbon deposition, and Co catalyst could be oxidated as well as carbon deposition, both of the condition could inactivate the catalyst [39,40]. The result is consistent with the TG analysis of Co-Al-SBA-15 and Co/Ni-Al-SBA-15 in the air (Fig. 7 ). There is a continued downward trend in the TG curve of Co-Al-SBA-15, which is corresponding to the mass loss of carbon deposition in the catalysts in the air. However, for the TG curve of Co/Ni-Al-SBA-15, there are two peaks. The mass loss peak in the range of 100–480°Cis attributed to the carbon deposition. And the mass increased peak in the range of 481–710 is corresponding to the oxidation of Ni or Co. However, the mass increase peak didn’t appear in the TG curve of Co-Al-SBA-15, which induced that the Co was fully oxidized during the catalyst reforming. Moreover, the loaded active metals dispersed on the surface of Al-SBA-15 to provide active spot, which attracted more reactant. Moreover, with the H2 concentration changing, the concentration of CO and CO2 changed as well. Before the reaction, there are no any carbon deposition on the fresh catalyst. However, the carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst was produced during the reaction, then CO2 would react with the carbon to produce CO. Fe and Sn did not enhance catalytic activity, when Fe-Al-SBA-15 was used as the catalyst, hydrogen content remained at approximately 30% throughout the entirety of the reaction. By contrast, when Sn-Al-SBA-15 was used as the catalyst, hydrogen yield decreased at 10min of reaction and eventually stabilized at approximately 25%. Hydrogen yields with Fe-Al-SBA-15 and Sn-Al-SBA-15 as catalysts were lower than that with pure Al-SBA-15 as catalyst because the addition of Fe and Sn increased overall catalytic selectivity, thus inhibiting the reaction of CH4 and reforming. 3.2.2 Effect of bimetallic loading on catalytic performance As shown by the results of the reaction with monometallic catalysts, adding Ni could increase catalytic activity but shorten the lifetime of the catalyst as well. Therefore, catalytic reformation with bimetallic (Ni-Co, Ni-Fe, and Ni-Sn)-SBA-15 and carbon deposition on the catalysts were investigated. The variations in gas concentration during the reaction catalyzed by the three catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 8 . Hydrogen content was also observed. Hydrogen content remained relatively stable when the three bimetallic catalysts were used to catalyze the reaction. Catalytic reformation with the Ni-Sn catalyst exhibited the highest hydrogen yield (approximately 52%), whereas that with the Ni-Fe catalyst exhibited a hydrogen yield of approximately 45%. The monometallic Ni and Co catalysts showed good catalytic activity. The hydrogen content of catalytic reformation with the Ni or Co catalyst was approximately 50%, and H2 concentration from the three kind of bimetallic catalyst were lower than those with monometallic catalysts at beginning, however, Ni/Co and Ni/Sn bimetallic catalyst are more stable than monometallic catalysts. The addition of Co would accelerate the carbon transfer to CO2, because Co is more compatible with oxygen spices. The addition of Sn decrease the possibility of the carbon deposited. And Sn would combine with Ni to form the Ni/Sn alloy and the formation will decrease active spot on the Ni particle surface, thus Ni/Sn bimetallic catalyst did not have better performance at catalytic activity, however it is more stable [25]. The improved catalytic performance of bimetallic catalysts resulted from the existence of auxiliaries, which enhanced the attraction of reaction products, increased reaction opportunities, increased catalytic selectivity, and decreased carbon deposition, thus prolonging the lifetime of the catalysts. 3.3 Effect of loaded metals on catalysts characterization SEM images for Sn-SBA-15, Ni-SBA-15, and Ni-Sn-SBA-15 are shown in Fig. 9 . The blank control did not show any obvious particles on the surface. The combined SEM and EDX results for Sn-SBA-15 indicated the presence of a Sn chain. This finding suggested that Sn, which has a low melting point, melted and was adsorbed on the carrier surface after reduction and thermal treatment. This finding further explained the poor catalytic performance of Sn-SBA-15. Some particles were observed on the surface of the Ni-SBA-15 catalyst, indicating that Ni existed on the carrier (about 100nm). Individual particles on the Ni/Sn-SBA-15 surface exhibited uniform distribution and particle size. In addition, no dissolved metals were present on the Ni-SBA-15 surface. The particle size of Ni/Sn-SBA-15 was larger (about 150nm) than that of Ni-SBA-15, this finding might have been caused by the combination of Ni with melted Sn. Hou [41] get the same result when they study the methane reforming catalyst, they found that the addition of Sn will make the Ni particle bigger. XRD and XPS analyses were conducted on the four catalysts Sn-Al-SBA-15, Ni-Al −SBA-15, Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 and SBA-15. The XRD results are presented in Fig. 10 . XPS mainly focused on Al and the loaded Ni (Fig. 10). As shown in Fig. 9(a), the blank control had no evident peaks, indicating that Al was uniformly distributed in Al-SBA-15. Ni-Al-SBA-15 showed an evident NiO peak. Sn-Al-SBA-15 presented a characteristic SnO peak. This finding suggested that the loaded active substances existed as oxides on the surface of Al-SBA-15. However, in Sn/Ni-Al-SBA-15, the characteristic peaks of the two oxides remained and no new characteristic peak was detected. Fig. 9(b) showed the reduced catalyst XRD results, the blank control still had no evident peaks, while the Sn-Al-SBA-15 and Ni-Al −SBA-15 showed sharp Sn and Ni feature peaks respectively, and Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 showed Ni3Sn2 alloy and Ni feature peaks. It indicates that Ni and Sn combines together during the processing of reduction. And there are more Ni article dispersing on the catalyst. Nikolla [42] also found Ni and Sn can form Ni/Sn alloy on the surface of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 11 , the binding energy of Al in Al-SBA-15 was 74.7eV. The binding energy of Al after Sn loading was 74.46eV but the bonding energy after Ni loading decreased to 73.99eV and shifted to 74.02eV after Ni-Sn loading. These findings suggested that no electron transfer occurred between the loaded active substances in the carrier. After Ni loading, Al showed new peaks and a binding energy of 67.49eV. After Ni-Sn loading, binding energy decreased to 63.01eV, indicating that the existence of Sn shifted the Al peak to the direction with lower binding energy. The peaks with low binding energy may be attributed to the formation of Ni-Al spinel. Based on the XPS analysis of Ni, distinct NiO peaks occurred on the 2P1/2 and 2P2/3 orbits. The binding energy of the NiO characteristic peak on the 2P1/2 orbit was 872.50eV, which was 0.70eV higher than that of NiO (871.80eV). The binding energy of the NiO characteristic peak on the 2P2/3 orbit conformed with that of NiO. However, a new peak corresponded to NiAl2O4 was observed at 855.73eV in the 2P2/3 orbit. During Ni loading, the interaction between Ni and Al increased the binding energy of inner electrons. Thus, Ni and Al bonded as NiAl2O4. After the addition of Sn, the binding energies of Ni remained constant but the peak area of NiAl2O4 increased and that of NiO decreased, further confirming that the addition of Sn benefits the combination of Ni and Al. 3.4 Experiment on the life of bimetallic catalysts Compared with monometallic catalysts, bimetallic catalysts had superior catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance. Changes in bimetallic catalysts during the long catalytic process were further explored. A comparative catalytic experiment was conducted using the Ni-Sn catalyst and the Ni (15%) monometallic catalyst. During 16h of catalytic reformation, the statistics for gas change were calculated in Fig. 12 . As showed in Fig. 12, both of the catalyst have a stable performance at the first 4h, however the H2 concentration via Ni monometallic catalytic reforming decreased at the fifth hour. After 16h reaction, the H2 concentration with the Ni monometallic catalyst decreased from 50% to 35%, while the H2 concentration with the Ni/Sn bimetallic catalyst remained 40%. Although the H2 concentration from the Ni-Sn (15% Ni and 5% Sn) catalysts decreased periodically, it remained at 50% for approximately 4h, then decreased to 45% and maintained at 45% for an additional 4h, finally decreased to 40% and maintained at 40%. The stability of Ni/Sn/Al-SBA-15 is higher than other catalysts such as Ni/Fe/γ-Al2O3, which was also used in the catalytic reforming of wood vinegar and it was not stable even at the first 1h[5]. Moreover, it was possible the composition was too complex that most of the catalyst was stable at 3h and then the activity decreased sharply [43]. SEM, EDS and TG analyses were performed to investigate carbon deposition on the two types of catalysts. Fig. 13 shows the SEM images of the spent catalysts. After catalysis experiment, both types of catalysts showed different degrees of particle adhesion. The Ni-Al-SBA-15 catalyst showed more adhered particles with various shapes and sizes. Moreover, most of the Ni particles were covered by carbon deposits. The surface of the spent Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 exhibited few carbon deposits. Moreover, the shapes and sizes of the carbon particles on the spent Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 were nearly the same as those on the fresh catalyst. Fig. 14 shows the EDS results of the two spent catalysts, the result further reflected that the bimetallic catalysts could inhibit carbon deposition. Both of the EDS results show the C content is 33.03w.t% on the Ni-Al-SBA-15 and 13.6w.t% on the Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15, respectively, while the Ni content was 5.5w.t% and 15.01wt.% respectively. It is obvious that bimetallic catalysts shows a better carbon deposition resistance. It is possible that Ni is the main active spot, the carbon deposit nearby the active spot and inhibits the catalytic reforming reaction. Therefore, the surface had less Ni content than the fresh catalyst, however the addition of Sn decreased the carbon deposition. In Nichio’s research [44], he had found that Sn occupied some active spot on the Ni before the carbon deposit on the spot, thus the addition of Sn improved the carbon deposition resistance of the catalyst. Fig. 15 shows the results of the TG analysis (in air atmosphere) for the spent catalysts after 5h of reaction time. The monometallic Ni-Al-SBA-15 catalyst presented two mass loss peaks during oxidization, losing approximately 2% due to the carbon deposits on its surface. The mass of the bimetallic catalyst increased gradually as the temperature increased. The reduced Ni, Sn, Ni-Sn, and Ni-Al in the catalyst likely reacted with O2 in air and formed metallic oxides, thus increasing the mass of the catalysts and indicating that numerous active centers of Ni, Sn and Ni-Sn remained in the spent bimetallic catalyst. Moreover, the TG curve of Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 exhibited no obvious mass loss peak. These findings suggested the low amount of carbon deposition on the Ni/Sn-SBA-15 catalysts. The probable reaction mechanism of the Ni/Sn-SBA-15 catalysts was showed in Fig. 16 , When reactants across the catalyst, due to the active site of the catalyst surface has the affinity to the reactants, once the reactants contact the active site, it will form H bond connected the active site and CC, then reaction activation energy of reactant was reduced to achieve the acceleration of reforming reaction. The followed equation(1–6) may be the possible process of the catalyst reforming reaction. (1) C x H y O z → C m H n O j +kH 2 O+uC+gases ( H 2 ,CO,CO 2 ,CH 4 ,C 2 H 4 , ⋯ ,C f H f+2 ) (2) C x H y + xH 2 O → xCO+ ( x+y/2 ) H 2 ( steam reforming ) (3) C x H y + xCO 2 → ( 2 x ) CO+ ( y/2 ) H 2 ( dry reforming ) (4) CH 4 + H 2 O → 3 H 2 + CO ( steam reforming methane reaction ) (5) CO + H 2 O → H 2 + CO 2 ( water gas shift reaction ) (6) C + H 2 O → H 2 + CO ( water gas reaction ) 4 Conclusion (1) Al-SBA-15 catalysts with different Al loading contents were prepared through one-step hydrothermal synthesis. The properties of the Al-SBA-15 samples were tested by BET, small angle XRD and XRF. Results showed that the Al-SBA-15 catalyst achieved mesoscopic ordering. (2) Rich H2 was produced through the catalytic reformation of PA (camellia shell oil) with monometallic Ni, Fe, Co and Sn (M-Al-SBA-15) and bimetallic Ni/Fe, Ni/Sn, and Ni/Co (M/N-Al-SBA-15) catalysts. Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 showed excellent catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance. H2 yield was 30.1mg/g, whereas H2 content was approximately 40% after 16h of reaction. (3) SEM results revealed that bimetallic Ni/Sn was distributed on the carrier surface (the particle size is about 150nm). XPS results showed that Ni formed a NiAl2O4 spinel with Al in the carrier, and that the involvement of Sn facilitated the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel between Ni and Al. EDS and TG results indicated that the bimetallic Ni-Sn catalyst prevented the formation of carbon deposition. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen gas was produced from the catalytic reformation of pyroligneous acid (PA)with modified bimetallic Al-SBA-15 catalysts. Al-SBA-15 catalysts with different aluminum loading contents were prepared through one-step hydrothermal synthesis. Monometallic M-Al-SBA-15 (M=Ni, Fe, Co, and Sn) and bimetallic M/N-Al-SBA-15 (M-N=Ni-Fe, Ni-Sn, and Ni-Co) catalysts were synthesized through impregnation. The catalysts were characterized via N2 adsorption-desorption, scanning electron microscopy(SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(XRD), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(XPS) analysis and so on. Bimetallic M-N-Al-SBA-15 catalysts exhibited higher catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance than monometallic M-Al-SBA-15 catalysts. Sn facilitated the combination of Ni with Al into a NiAl2O4 spinel in the carrier. Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 bimetallic catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity and carbon deposition resistance. The H2 yield was 30.1mg/g and H2 content remained 40% after 16h under the optimal reaction conditions via the Ni/Sn-Al-SBA-15 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen from pyroligneous acid via modified bimetal Al-SBA-15 catalysts
